comment: Haven't had it yet, really want to try it though.
A little chocolatey on the nose. For something so peated, it is daaaaaaaaaamn smooth.
Amazing! I was going to buy another bottle of the 18 yr after seeing this was rated lower. Glad I decided to give Dark Origins a try, my favorite scotch!
This has the distinctive HP nose and palate, but good God is it sweet!  This one's not for me.
Pair with a porter when drinking and it's amazing.  Great finish definitely adding it
perfect balance of peat and sweet sherry , helps accent vanilla , apricot and subtle spice .. Great value and undeniably HP
Sherry is ever-present, to be sure. But hints of vanilla, citrus, and a touch of tobacco shine through on the palate. Spicy on the finish. Highland Park continues to impress!
Industrial! Motor oil, chocolate, stewed fruits. The sulphur is well integrated. Not bad!
Lovely caramel and citrus notes on the nose. Smoky but not too dark. Love it
Caramel & Citrus Notes. When paired with chocolate, coffee & cocoa notes. H20 lends to sweeter notes. Mild smokey start with a sweet finish.

Tasted at Hunger n' Thirst, Lancaster, PA. A little hot at first. Earthy sweet peat smoke. Rich raisin-heavy sherry and sea salt, all combining to create a smoky salted-caramel flavor. (Gives the impression of a vegetarian Lagavulin, if that can't be taken as a slight...) Added water increases the sweetness and forms an estimable scotch mist! Risky on the palate; Hot oak, mild pear and nutty. Quick finish, Sweet smoke returns. It's definitely enjoyable, but not exceptional, and woefully overpriced for a NAS.

Lots of first fill barrels ball Spanish oak sherry cask. Bottles at 46.8% and non chill filter. Chewy whisky and smokier- smokiest hp to date. Adding water opens up the expression to creamier, toffee, caramel

I hesitated trying this but am very glad I finally got around to trying and buying. I am a huge fan of HP and this is  great whisky. I have heard comments that it is harsh or rough round the edges. Maybe they changed the bottling slightly from when it was first released. This is a really great example of what HP can produce. Typical HP smoke and honey with great sherry flavors. You must try this whisky!

Strong sherry for me. Some tobacco on the back. Lots going on up front. I'm new to highland park. Probably should have explored more of their entry level bottles. Bottle looked cool. I'm a sucker for paint and font.

Very impressed. 
Nose: sherry, honey, heather, Ash,  smoke, brine, hint of sulphur,inviting sticky sweetness, damp sherry soaked infused wood chips
Palate: full on super sweet sherry attack wow wow wow, smoke lingering, spiciness, ashy, super sweet, milk chocolate
Finish: spicy, sherry sherry sweet sweetest,  sherry sweetness remains

Hmm where to begin. First I gotta say that this is VERY different from the 12 and 18. This is really good, honestly my favorite highland park. This is like the 12's assertiveness with the 18's richness turned up 46.8% but richer and more flavourful. This is a sherry bomb with the heather,  briney, highland park smoke. The sherry is really nice, it's close to overwhelming all the other flavours but I don't mind because I like big powerful whiskies. I'd give it 5/5 but for a NAS at only 46.8% at $100 it puts it in territory of other really good scorches.
Complex flavor combinations. Sweetness with a dose of peat and smoke reminiscent of many Islay whiskies, like a Highland-Islay bridge.

This is a good benchmark for the beginning of the spectrum of flavors for mild peat, mildly sweet, full bodied with many flavors including a little tobaccon vanilla, caramel and slight orange all supporting a nice sherry tone.

Grabbed this scotch on a whim and boy am I glad I did.  Now I've had highland park 18 before and love the distillery, but this one, this one is very nice. 

Kick of peat, nice weight and mouthfeel, a little heat, and long linger. 

Pop on some songs from the rat pack, sit in a leather chair, and explore this one.  It's a winner.
Has the rich and sweetness you would expect from a sherry cask with the smoke and tobacco of Highland Park.  Very nice
A much better experience for me than the 12 yr.  I would compare it to the HP 18 only lacking as much of the smokiness to round it all out.  A solid everyday drinker.
Sweet, yet mild mix with smoke and fruits, very smooth and creamy.
Raisins, a bit of brininess, smoke/mild peat on finish.

The color is a gorgeous amber, and the taste is just as full and rich as you would hope. Sweet and smooth to start, giving way to ashy tobacco smoke on the finish. A nice lingering spicy tingle, but not too hot. Excellent whisky.
Raisins, honey and a touch of brine on the nose.  Sweet sherry but surprisingly smokey and chocolate notes.  The finish is spicy and hot, but has sherry sweetness.  This is delicious

The sherry is prominant and dominant on nosing.  Give it time to open and the aromas of light brown sugar, some dark fruits, dates or figs, and a pinch of brine waft around.  A touch of tobacco is first to arrive and opens to almonds and/or walnuts and a touch of oak.  They all gradually fade and leave the mouth slightly oaken with a touch of grapefruit and white pepper spice.  Add a small amount of water and the dram is rounder and sweeter and strengthens the grapefruit on the finish.  Preferable with water.  This is a slightly more concentrated and tighter version of HP12 where the flavors are slightly amped-up.  Makes a wonderful sipper that is best enjoyed when there is time and the bustle of everyday can be pushed aside for a little bit.  Many thanks Pranay for the generous sample.  I was waiting for that moment to sit back to concentrate and enjoy this dram.  Much enjoyed.  [Dried glass: Brown sugar and vanilla][90/100][9/2/16]

It may have the sherry but it is a pleasant sweetness. That blends wonderfully with a smoky flavor. There is a touch of spicy bite in the middle, but it all smooths out nicely in the end and leaves you wishing for more.

Appearance- the color of Dark Origins is very deserving of its name, it is visibly darker than others from this distillery
Nose- sweet floral smoke of pipe tobacco mingled with spiked fruit punch
Body- the fruit fragrance fades here while the floral sweetness comes through mingling with woody vanilla and light peat
Finish- a very warm finish with  spiciness of red pepper comes through in the finish giving way to a return in pipe smoke that lingers lightly 
Note- I was pleasantly surprised by the easy transition this dram provides from un peated sherried scotches to a peated scotch. I purchased this for Dad for Father's Day but liked it so much that it will now play a permanent role in my own collection.  I will continue on my journey with this distillery and look forward to the next discovery. 18 year?
I still prefer the 12 but this is a damn good Scotch!
Really good whisky! Great long lasting taste.
I love it, so delicious and rich but getting hard to find :(
2017 San Francisco World Spirit Competition Award Winner
Sherry... but tolerable to me. Sweeter on the nose than taste. But still sweet.

Solid HP! There's everything you can expect from this Orkney distillery: sherry, tobacco and pepper. The dram is light and hardly peated, with a finish that is smooth and wonderful. Definitely worth the $100 CAD.
Very Smokey! Tobacco on the nose and finish.
Surprisingly odd. Big chocolate flavor, unexpected.
Reminds me a lot of the 12 year, but more sweetness.  On the nose: sweet, gummi Bears, fruit.  Taste: sweet fruit, vanilla, honey, Peat smoke, more heat on the end.

Light peat, dark chocolate, and notes of citrus on the nose. Sweet and silky mouthful, with dried plums and hints of fudge on the palate. Light smoke and medium length finish. Smooth, tasty and worth a try.

Fancy bottle, marketing-driven NAS presentation and a hefty price tag: why on earth would I review Highland Park Dark Origins? Because it's surprisingly good! Heavy sherry aroma with spices, baked apple and distant peat smoke greets the nose. I get raisins, dates, polished wood and, oddly enough, menthol cigarettes. The taste is sweet, then astringent, before the sweetness returns with walnuts, black tea and well-measured sherry cask influence. After a savory and mildly peaty finish, I must confess I am almost sad that this whisky has been discontinued.

RATING: 3.9/5.0 stars ≙ 86 pts → FIRST-CLASS [-]

I swear that I am no where near a bottle of Ardbeg Uigeadail, but the nose on this is eerily similar. Maybe also some lapsang souchong, as I usually also detect from Lagavulin 16. On the palate neat, it's a nice smoke, but I miss that oily mouth coat.  That maybe from immaturity. Smelled a bit like a port, but the taste brought the peat. This is not super duper hot, just a little, so let's just drop a few small drops on this and see what happens.  The intense chocolate fudge is still there, maybe even more so.  The sherry finally comes through a  bit more, which I wanted, without losing the pepper and peat. Better mouth feel, and less burn.  With just a few drops of water, I'd say a 2.8-2.9 , so I'll round up a smidgen to a 3.  Glad I tried it on vacation this week.  The color says natural, but it is intensely dark. I wish I knew the ages of what's going on here.
The base HP is very very interesting treated with the sherry overtop. A wonderful discovery!
12/2016 at Kupros w Masami. Sherry finish w peat, complex,
It is good, like all Highland Park offerings. But, while good, it is not as nice as the 12 or 18. A little too much sherry...but it doesn't mellow the overall like most sherry whisky's.

I finally got around to opening this bottle.  If you've tried the HP 12 and liked it, this is by far better.  The nose screams Sherry through and through.   It has the aroma of traditional Sherry based Highlander like a Macallan, but then quickly lets you know on the palette that it's really an islander, and undeniably a HP.  Tabacco, almonds, grapefruit, vanilla.  A bit salty, but not like a Talisker.  Finish is quick and hot---young definately, but who cares if it's a NAS and still good.  Question is:  is it worth close to $90?   Not sure...I think so, yes.
Really enjoyable complex nose with brine and tobacco. Hot on the tongue and overwhelms the finish.
sweet, a little heat, smooth, vanilla & caramel?, not super complex. tobacco on aftertaste. grew on me over time.

Thanksgiving 2017
More sherry than peaty
It’s okay; I much prefer Lagavulin
Perfectly fine and not much more. Drying sherry dominates and peat shyly lingers on the finish. Cool bottle though.

Dark Origins. Cool name. Good looking bottle. And fortunatly, good whisky. On the nose I get plums, some dark honey notes, hint of citrus and a bit of stale pipe tobacco. Plums continue on the palate, together with more vanilla, dark chocolate and the typical barley. Light, fruity sweetness in the background. Spicy, sweet and plummy aftertaste. Good stuff.

The bottom line here is that Highland Park has produced a sweeter, peatier version of Highland Park 12 with more rough edges.  The nose takes a while to settle down and initially reeks of an earthy, almost sour peat that reminds me of compost or spoiled vegetables.  Thankfully, after 10-15 minutes, that unpleasant scent subsides into a much better roast coffee aroma.  Dark Origins reveals its sherried components on the palate, with lots of dark fruit flavors, raisins, some orange, and tendrils of smoke.  The palate is moderately oily and has a decent mouthfeel to boot.  It finishes on that strong coffee note, which I find to be a Highland Park signature, like a slightly peatier version of the 12.  At $80 when it was available, this strikes me as half a solid scotch and half a cash grab.
Very nice. Had at VOX Austin. Spicy, some smoke, a nice scotch.

Nose - Sweet sherried smoke, almost like a dark red wine being mulled with a bunch of dark dried stone fruits over a campfire in a kettle.

Taste - Like eating a prune that's been re-hydrated with a sweet white wine heated over a wood heated campfire, lightly drying mouthfeel with a hint of oaky bitter, like a charred oak branch fell in your mulled red wine.

Finish - Lingering charred fruit bittersweet, light smoke, hint of medicinal sweet.

Score - 75/100

Final Thoughts - I enjoyed the nose on this one but after that it fell a bit flat. It became dominated by a sweet smoky fruit and that's about it. Light spicy notes at the end, but the medicinal fruity smoky finish reminded me a bit of a sweet band-aid which was a bit off putting. I'm glad I only got a sample of this as I think I'd be a bit disappointed if I had a full bottle of this, especially at WA State prices.
Somewhat sweet, def smoky (not too), but more peaty than HP12, strongest on the finish, sherry notes bc barrels; woodsy barrel finish.
Had sampler from Highland Park 15 year bottle. Much smokier than HP 15, and still nicely peaty.

Moderately casky with light flavor of peat. Smooth with no burn. I generally don't like heavy wood or peat in my scotch but this is good for when I want something heavier than my normal highland range of liquors.
Kind of boozy, high-proof. Wasn’t my first of the night, so try again.

Really solid scotch. 
Significant burn but a good kinda burn. 

A little Peet in there but it’s not overwhelming.  

A little Carmel in there on the second sniff
Meeting with George at Wing’s in Bexley.
Orange, Vanilla, and Tobacco. The description couldn’t have said it any better.
Starts with a peat flavor and finishes sweet with lingering spice
Lite peaty a hint of sweetness.
Pretty good, not the best of the Highland Park products. 3.5

I always forget not to have this as my first drink of the night. It's so hot!! I just started working at a tobacco shop and suddenly I get the tobacco note everyone's talking about. This pour is super delicious, the epitome of 'burns so good'.
Impressively dark thanks to the double first fill sherry casks. Definitely tastes like a 17 year old at least. Still a great value to be had now. 93
See HP 12 then override it with intense tangerine, cranberries and a touch of cough syrup.

I think sherry finish to scotch is what bourbon barrel is to beer. That is, they're using it for everything nowadays. That said, this was a well done iteration. I approve. Had it in a flight against HP 12 and HP Full Volume. Dark Origins came out on top.
Quite possibly the best scotch I’ve ever tried.  It’s very well rounded and packed full of flavor from start to finish without being abrasive or overpowering.
A great introduction into the peated/smoky world; especially if you are coming from the Bourbon side.  This is discontinued so get before it’s gone.

One of my favorite scotches, maybe my absolute favorite. It’s got Orkney peat, its got smoke, it’s got brine, honey, heather, light citrus, sherry cask dark fruit...it’s got everything. A bit aggressive but I like that. It’d be worth the original msrp of $80, but I hunted down 3 bottles clearanced for $40. Bummer they discontinued this! But it has made me a HP fan.

Nose: orange, honey, vanilla cream and slight raspberry

Palate: hint of barrel tannins, soft peat (not like a laphroig), ends with honey and raspberry.

Overall:  the Oak and Sherry barrels are very present in this whisky and for a NAS it comes across as an old whisky.  It is very smooth with nearly no alcohol burn and is inviting keeping you coming back for more
Nose has pleasant blend of sherry and Smokey peat. Palate tastes of campfire, peat, sea salt and sherry. Finish is shorter than anticipated and very smooth.

I find Whiskey hunting can sometimes be like a good game of Poker. Sometimes you just get on a hot streak after a bit of a frost and you just need to ride that streak! This month has been that way for me with Single Malts specifically! This is one I stumbled upon for $49.97! At that price, I felt the value was too good to pass up with this being discontinued and given that I quite enjoyed the pour I had of the 12 yr old expression. 
I am quite partial to a heavily Sherried single malt and the fact it's Peated is just a bonus for me. On to the tasting! 
Right upon entry I get some initial smoke which quickly fades to reveal orange peel, toasted walnuts, wood and a hint of old leather. Red fruits become noticable on the mid pallette with campfire marshmallows leading to a medium to long finish with oak, sherry, smoke and a hint of brine. I taste the subtle maritime notes as the finish fades. 
There is for sure some noticable astringency that I associate with old Whisky's. As this is an NAS offering it's anyone's guess how much older stock is in it. Based on the notes I am getting I am convinced there is some pretty old stock in the blend (notes I definitely didn't get with the 12 yr). Lovely pour and I am happy to have bought the bottle! 
At the $80+ price point it typically goes for, I would call this a fair-ish value. At the $49.97 price point it's a steal for sure. My one critique would be it's a bit heavy to be a frequent pour, but one that will go into my after dinner rotation for sure! Cheers all!

The nose is wonderfully balanced of peat, smoke, dried fruit, sea salt and some vanilla. The palate is smoky but not overwhelming, followed by cinnamon, creamy toffee, dried fruit sweetness and oak. The finish is medium long with fading peat, smoke, leather and toffee.
Light smoke, plum, cherry, butterscotch, more dark fruit

Got this for Birthday 18. 

can taste the sherry. Tastes like Laphroaig 10 year in Sherry to me.
Smooth with a nice level of peat.
Strong and sweet nose. Dark grassy notes, very light peat smoke. Tannic finish

Representing isle of orkeny

Nose: neat loads of sherry, apricot, sea salt, orange peel, light puff of smoke. With water, waaay more sea salt and sherry, light honey, light caramel

Body:  medium to full

Palate: peppery & spicy, oaky, smoky, tobacco in the late finish. Sherry in the middle and end. With water, still sherry predominates more orange late. 

Finish: long really nice, loooooong. With classic tobacco

Note: this is really good, less refined than HP18, edges are rougher but really very very good.

Think Glenlivrt Founders Reserve but with the full body and character of typical of most Isle scotch.

N: citrus, honey, fruity, rich, sweet

P: Sweet, fruity with vanilla on the tongue, touch of peat?, citrusy orange note peaking through reminds me of orange creamcicle

F: Sweet and smooth, if it weren't for the back up fruity notes this would literally taste like I just ate an orange creamcicle with a touch of peat.

I like this bc the orange comes out of nowhere on the back and lasts into the finish. If you want this straight, DO IT! Would be my preference. Could see this as an interesting choice in Cocktails. Definitely would need it to be spirit driven to not lose complexity.

Nez: butterscotch, boisé, fumé 

Goût: smoke

Nose: unmistakeable sherry notes on the nose. These aren’t sweet fruits though. I smell something closer to cranberry, maybe prune? 
Palate: I don’t find chocolate, but it does have fruity notes. Maybe the chocolate I was looking for was milk, while this was dark. Maybe dark chocolate, it doesn’t taste the 46%. It’s watered down. Didn’t taste as well as I remembered 
Finish: smoke
Sweet and spicy, more bourbon notes than a typical highland. Very good.
Good smoke, peaty and smooth. Mild alcohol burn, pleasant

This NAS Highland Park dram is excellent. It boasts that it is the kin of the Highland Park 18, as it should. The nose is rich and promising, and the honeycomb note I associate with Highland Park is present here. On the palate this whisky is initially salty. A quenching minerality accompanies luxe notes of black plum and cardamom. The peat and sherry partner stunningly in Dark Origins. The waxy Highland Park trademark is limited to the nose this time, as the mouthfeel is actually somewhat  oily. I enjoy a malty and spicy finish and a decadently oaken aftertaste. A truly excellent whisky.

The nose has honeycomb, minerals, heather, orange tang, and peat.  The smoke phenols are grassy, like a dried, dead overgrowth entwined with cooked fruits from the sherry casking.  Palate has spiced apples, fruitcake, candied nuts, brown raisins, and brine.  The finish shifts sharply toward black pepper and an unusual herbal fruit note not unlike junipers--rather uncharacteristic but a welcome distinctive in this fairly short but poignant finish.  Also finishing are smoked meats and musty wood.

Neat. Served in cold glass :(
Just tasted acidity and alcohol aftertaste.

Nose:  Caramel, Hint of Smoke, Honey
Palate: Slight Sherry, Vanilla, Smoke, Pepper
Finish: Peat

Can’t complain about the nose or the palate. The finish is pretty terrible though and more or less out of control.
22-22-18-19=81

Nose: vanilla, Sherry, orange
Taste: mild smoke, Sherry, Christmas cake, 
Finish: not very long, but of a burn

HIGHLAND PARK DARK ORIGINS
sherry cask- first-fill 80%/ re-fill 20%
(46.8%)

증류소 설립자이자 위스키 밀매업자였던 매그너스 은순의 어두운 역사를 상징적으로 표현

향 : 오렌지의 등장, 은은한 스모키, 연기를 머금은 쉐리, 연기에 가려서 많은 향이 가려짐
맛 : 향기나는 꽃과 꿀, 은은한 스모키, 맛나는 곡물, 
피니쉬 : 연기 속 흘러나오는 약한 피티함, 

# 간결하고 정갈하게 담고있는 하이랜드파크의 오리진

I have a weakness for highland park, because i love it's marketing. Dark Origins is all about a lovely smugglers story who not only founded the distillery ilegally, but also had secret ways to sell the whisky to the public.

Bottled at 46.8%abv; auburn poslished mahogany color, lovely.

On the nose a very soft peat note, not what you expect from your typical Highland Park. Brownies, Slight Tobbacco, Fresh forest, a Slight salt note and Garlic bread. A little dissapointed on the nose, it made me think i was in front of a bad dram... how wrong i was about it.

On the palate is was awesome: Caramel, Orange, Brownies, Oaky, Acid, big Smoke note, some Salt and Clove. Finish was long and salty with hints of smoke and bonfire.

Overall this dram is an 89 over 100, points deducted on the nose but definitively a good whisky.
